instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U4900: What is U4900? This is the System Management Controller(SMC) in older(pre-2013) macbooks.
definitions.SMC_TCK: What is SMC_TCK? SMC_TCK is a signal that must be pulled up to 3.42v in order for the SMC to be in the proper mode to function. Often this is not pulled up because of corrosion or corroded resistors by the SMC. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message:
Have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has no liquid damage, it supposedly just suddenly died. currently no green light. I have replaced isl <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> since I was getting 18V on pin 2  but 0v from pin 14. Same results.

here are some voltages

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.42v

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.40v

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.42V

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0V

Is this bad smc?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message:
Check first power rails and signals for SMC (<CHIP>U4900</CHIP> - 2 of 2), page 45.
You can try to reball it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message: I think it's more likely there is just crap under it as you have 12.4 volts. I'd say remove the edge bonding and run flux under it and heat it. That will clear out any crap under it, and I would bet solves the issue. Also, you could have a bad ISL/poorly soldered ISL, but fluxing the SMC is easiest to do first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message:
Replaced SMC with a known good SMC but still same results. There was no crap under old SMC either

<SIGNAL>PM_CLK32K_SUSCLK_R</SIGNAL>  is only 0.15V, could this mean bad PCH?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message:
PCH requires 3V3SUS to send out <SIGNAL>PM_CLK32K_SUSCLK_R</SIGNAL>.

Post resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> (diode mode, red to ground).
Check voltages and signals for SMC (<CHIP>U4900</CHIP> - 2 of 2) at page 45.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message:
everything was working perfect including booting into OS but after going through the ultrasonic cleaner I have a dead board again.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> only 0.690V

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> 0.434 resistance to ground

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message:
"after going through the [URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/crest-p500h-45.html"]ultrasonic[/URL] cleaner I have a dead board again"
Do you have UC whitout sweep function, or don't use it?
Because I don't see other reason to damage the board...
Could be more dificil to fix the board now, than before.

Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message: Sometimes also you might not have driven out all the liquid from under the chips like the CPU/PCH .  Make sure you put it through the distilled water flush + alcohol + low bake + cool off;  a couple of times I've had boards not start up after being in USC that ended up being because I was impatient and didn't give the board a chance to properly dry off.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message:
Resistance to ground PP3V42 0.768

Not sure if my UC has sweeper or not, I use the crest P500H Louis recommended on the youtube channel years ago. He never mentioned about a sweeper function.

pin 2 17.80V

pin 12 3.42v

pin 14 0v

Have short to ground  ON <SIGNAL>SMC_TCK</SIGNAL> Resistor <RESISTOR>R5080</RESISTOR>  came off along with corroded pad in UC. Have tried jumper wire but still no luck. Short is there even without <RESISTOR>R5080</RESISTOR>. Is this unrepairable now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message: Paul Daniels didn't know and have never used a oven after a board has come out of UC. What kind of oven is recommended? Toaster oven?? How hot and how long should a board go in after alcohol bath?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message:
"short to ground ON <SIGNAL>SMC_TCK</SIGNAL>"
A resistor can never generate a short; unless is not covered by corrosion.
In fact <RESISTOR>R5080</RESISTOR> is the pull-up resistor, doesn't even go to ground.
Your problem is underneath SMC, or SMC itself shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message: with SMC off of the board I still have a short to ground of 0.000 on <SIGNAL>SMC_TCK</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message:
That means short inside board.
Follow the trace outside SMC and cut it off, trying to locate the part with short to ground.
Still possible to solve it, but not easy.
Very strange for a board without corrosion...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message: Yeah and I think TCK is for programming the SMC so you donâ€™t need it. Dig out the short if possible

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> bad smc?
threads.message:
I think SMC requires high level on TCK line for normal operating.
The signal is not used, but its level can be critical...
